urn:contentItem:6F1Y-2HS3-RVRW-W0WF-00000-00Firefighters in narrow escape, homes lost as state burns2025-02-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:41ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Firefighters in narrow escape, homes lost as state burnsCassandra Morgan and Lachlan Abbott

Three firefighters have narrowly escaped after their vehicle caught alight and was destroyed in Victoria's west, as crews face a dangerous wind change and further widespread extreme heat.

The NSW firefighters were battling the Little Desert National Park fire and managed to get out of their vehicle before it was fully engulfed about lunchtime yesterday.

A wind change today is expected to keep the Little Desert fires moving. In the Grampians National Park, the wind change will threaten communities to its north, fanning flames into unburned country, authorities warned. "What firefighters are trying to do at the moment is burn out that vegetation above those fires today and tonight, and try to take the sting out of those when the wind change comes through," Forest Fire Management Victoria chief Chris Hardman said yesterday.

"They will be very much prepared and planning for that, and doing everything they can to minimise the spread of those fires, but hot spots will show up, and it will challenge us when the wind direction changes."

Victoria was hit by hundreds of thousands of lightning strikes on Sunday, with the Bureau of Meteorology estimating about 50,000 reached the ground. The lightning was to blame for many of the 114 new fires sparked on Sunday.

The Little Desert fires, two fires in the Grampians and four fires in the Great Otway National Park continued to burn yesterday. Fire crews were confident they could secure three of the four fires in the Otways, and they would do all they could to control the "challenging" fourth blaze, Hardman said.

Two homes and an outbuilding at Nangiloc on the NSW border were destroyed in a fire on Sunday.

The State Emergency Service fielded about 950 calls for help on Sunday - among them, about 500 from Geelong, where storms dumped hail and ripped the roof off at least one home. Lara recorded 30 millimetres of rain within half an hour at one point on Sunday, while Mildura and Horsham reached a top of 43 degrees.

About 45,000 properties were without power at the peak of a widespread outage on Sunday. That number had dwindled to about 3500 by yesterday afternoon.

Melbourne Airport recorded a temperature of 38.6 about 3.10pm yesterday, while the mercury at Olympic Park peaked at 37.8 degrees just before 4pm, shy of the 38.5 degrees reached on Sunday afternoon. Viewbank in Melbourne's north-east tapped 39.3 degrees about 3.45pm.

Forecasters warned temperatures would remain warm overnight, and a heatwave warning is in effect until Thursday.

Today is predicted to bring some relief for southern Victoria, with a cool change developing in the state's south-west in the morning and reaching Melbourne early in the afternoon, the bureau's Michael Efron said.

The Environment Protection Authority has warned poor water quality is forecast at almost all beaches in Port Phillip Bay, rendering them not suitable for swimming.

urn:contentItem:6DP4-C6H3-RX3T-50PT-00000-00Creswick Melbourne Road fire now contained2024-12-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:41ZLexisNexisCreswick Melbourne Road fire now containedStaff reporters

But smoke will still be visible in the area.

The Creswick-Melbourne Road fire has been contained , but Forest Fire Management says smoke will still be visible in the area.

In their latest advice message, issued for residents of Dean, Springmount and Wattle Flat, north of Ballarat, they said there was low-level fire activity within the containment lines and that crews and aircraft would continue to work in the area.

Residents are asked to stay informed, monitor conditions and stay away from the area.

All roads have reopened, but speed restrictions are in place on the Creswick-Dean Road between Melbourne Road and Skilbecks Road and the Melbourne Road between Creswick-Dean Road and Russells Reservoir.

Internal forest tracks in the fire area remain closed, including Bush Inn Road.

The fire, which began on Monday, December 16 and burned through about 200 hectares, saw more than 300 firefighters and multiple fire brigades from across the region support firefighting efforts.

Farm fencing and water replacement

The state government says it will pay half the cost of boundary fencing upgrades, up to $5,000 per kilometre to replace or repair fencing between private land and all national parks and state forests destroyed or damaged by bushfires.

The government will also pay the restoration costs of fences damaged on private land from machinery used by fire agencies to control bushfires, or where fences have been cut to allow access for suppression.

Any water used by emergency services will be replaced.

urn:contentItem:6DRD-P373-RRKS-81PH-00000-00Roads closed as emergency services set up base in park2024-12-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:41ZLexisNexisNEWS3Roads closed as emergency services set up base in parkGwen Liu

'We are trying to minimise the impacts on regular park users.'

Victoria Park is being transformed into base camp for about 200 firefighters as a pre-emptive strike ahead of what looks to be a dangerous holiday period with hot weather and strong wind predicted.

Road closures in and around Victoria Park have been in place from Tuesday as a base camp was being set up at the site.

Last summer a similar camp was set up so emergency services fighting fires at Buangor, in February and March, had a base.

Working with Forest Fire Management Victoria and Country Fire Authority, the City of Ballarat said the base camp was to support the fire response in western Victoria.

Roads in and around Victoria Park will be closed to support the traffic management required for the camp.

The public will still have access to the Inclusive Play-Space and the parking lot.

The establishment of the base camp is expected to be done before expected fire weather hits today .

City of Ballarat chief executive Evan King said Ballarat is the perfect location for the base camp, enabling rapid distribution of resources across western Victoria.

"We are trying to minimise the impacts on regular park users, some roads within the park will need to be closed," Mr King said.

"Please be patient and understanding of the important work that's being done to assist our emergency service agencies.

"And with extreme weather conditions predicted ... it's also a timely reminder for us all to ensure our properties are fire ready - ensure your grass has been slashed and your gutters cleared.

"We all need to play our part."

A base camp is being built in Victoria Park. Picture supplied.

urn:contentItem:6DVM-CX33-RYD8-C4FW-00000-00Criminal probe launched after cause of Otways blaze revealed2025-01-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:41ZLexisNexisCriminal probe launched after cause of Otways blaze revealed

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Mark Buttler

An abandoned campfire caused this week's Otway Ranges bushfire, investigations have found.

A criminal inquiry has been launched to find who left the fire unattended, leading to a major blaze which threatened the safety of campers and other holiday-makers in the area.

Up to 150 of them were evacuated from camping grounds in the area in a major emergency operation.

The fire started in bush at Blanket Bay Rd and Red Hill Track at 2.20am on Wednesday and led to police having to set up drop-in centres for the displaced at Apollo Bay Community Hall and Apollo Bay Youth Hall

It burnt through 14 ha and had the potential to be engulf a much bigger expanse of the isolated area.

Investigators from Forest Fire Management, Colac CIU and the Victoria Police arson and explosives squad have found the blaze spread from an unextinguished campfire which had been abandoned.

Detectives have appealed for anyone who was in the vicinity of the Blanket Bay campground on Wednesday and who has dashcam or any other footage to come forward and call Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000 or visit www.crimestoppersvic.com.au.

Police have urged campers to remember a recklessly lit fire could have the same results as a deliberately lit fire, such as deaths, serious injury and property damage.

Detective Insp. Karl Curran of Victoria Police western region said what had happened was reckless conduct which could have had catastrophic consequences.

"Fortunately, emergency services worked quickly to get the fire under control, but as we know, this is not always the case."We are now investigating the fire, and if we do identify who started the campfire, they will be charged," Insp Curran said.

A conviction for being found guilty of recklessly or intentionally causing a bushfire carries a maximum penalty of 15 years imprisonment.

Inspector Chris Murray of the arson and explosives squad said the case was a reminder of the maxim that "if you light it, you own it".

"Recklessly lit fires can include things like disobeying restrictions relating to total fire bans or fire danger periods, leaving campfires unattended, or using machinery during hot weather," he said.

"Police will investigate and take action to catch those responsible when a fire is deemed suspicious, whether it was a deliberate or reckless action."

urn:contentItem:6D75-D0T1-JC0X-K0R8-00000-00VIC:Banking on seeds to help save endangered possum2024-10-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:41ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:Banking on seeds to help save endangered possumWODONGA Oct 20

  A battle to save a critically endangered possum is being fought on many fronts and multiple timelines.
   Victoria's Leadbeater's possum, known as "forest fairies" for their elusiveness, were thought to be extinct when they were rediscovered near Marysville in 1961.


   The state's faunal emblem, with its big eyes and bushy tail, relies on dense, damp areas in old growth forest and nests in hollows that take over 150 years to form.
   Less than 40 of the lowland subspecies exist today in a tract of the Yellingbo Forest, east of Melbourne, after most of its habitat was lost to logging and development.
   But a project spearheaded by state-owned statutory authority Melbourne Water aims to grow the creature's future habitat through a climate-modelled seed bank.
   The seeds have been collected from areas with climatic conditions similar to what is expected for the Yarra Valley in the next 25 to 65 years.
   The sources span from forests in Gippsland, in Victoria's southeast, to Wyong, north of Sydney.
   "We know that to save the lowland Leadbeater's possum from extinction, we need to protect and expand its habitat by growing forests that will be resilient to hotter, drier climates," Melbourne Water partnership coordinator Kacie Melfi said.
   Six species of native trees were shortlisted to help shore-up future habitat for the Leadbeater's possum.
   Melbourne Water is working with Zoos Victoria and Victoria's Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action to identify land that could provide future habitat for the species.
   A collaboration between Zoos Victoria and Monash University focuses on the creature's gene pool to assure its survival.
   The organisations have successfully bred a hybrid of the highland Leadbeater's subspecies with its lowland counterpart in captivity, to help stem the inbreeding depression in the latter variety.
   "We've got 39 (lowland) individuals left in the wild; that's just nine breeding pairs," Zoos Victoria field officer Arabella Eyre told AAP.
   "We're really excited that we've recently produced our first hybrid joey."
   Previous attempts to move the highland Leadbeater's possums from their ash forest and sub-alpine woodlands habitat in Victoria's Central Highlands into lowlands populations haven't been successful.
   "That's why testing in captivity and having the ability to test that mixing in a controlled environment is really important for us," Ms Eyre said.
   Another key feature of the conservation program is to temporarily house juveniles, who can be lost to predators like cats or by wandering into unsuitable habitat.
   "The problem being a possum is when you hit your teenage years and it's time to go find a mate, there's not that many options left in the wild," Ms Eyre said.
   "We're able to collect those sub adults just before they disperse, take them back to Healesville sanctuary and kind of play possum matchmaker and then re-release them into the wild."
   Habitat loss remains a major challenge.
   "We've cleared over 90 per cent of lowland Leadbeater's habitat; they were originally distributed all the way down to Koo Wee Rup and the Bass River, and now only in this single reserve," Ms Eyre said.
   "The story of the possum's decline is really a story of the loss of habitat."
   While Victoria's environment department was a partner in conservation efforts like the seed bank project, its Forest Fire Management Victoria branch was levelling thousands of hectares for strategic fire breaks, forest ecology expert David Lindenmayer said.
   "This is in complete conflict with other really important, direct things that we could do right now, like not knock the animals' nest trees down that are 300 or 400 years old, that are going to take centuries to regrow," he told AAP.
   "One part of the department is not talking to the other part of the department."
   Victoria banned commercial native logging in January but a dead endangered greater glider possum found near fire break works in the Yarra Ranges National Park in May reignited debate over the state's forests.
   "The reality is there's 18,000 hectares of forest that hasn't regenerated (after commercial logging), and we're knocking down 300 year old trees for firebreaks that don't work," Professor Lindenmayer said.
   He said research had shown for more than a decade that logged forests became more fire-prone.
   But the department argues fuel breaks retained far more trees and couldn't be compared to disused logging coupes.
   According to Forest Fire Management Victoria, asset protection fire breaks protect towns and public assets, while landscape protection breaks give firefighters access to blazes in the bush and to back-burn.
   The organisation has established 1447km of fuel breaks, between 20m and 40m wide across Victoria, and has funding to extend to 6000km of breaks by 2030.
   Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman said regeneration and fire breaks were a proven and effective tool against bushfires.
   "In the Upper Yarra catchment, fuel breaks help us keep bushfires small and therefore protect communities, assets such as Melbourne's main water supply, and the environment - including protecting the habitat of the vulnerable population of Leadbeater's possum from bushfires," Mr Hardman said in a statement.
Forest Fire Management Victoria maps show no new strategic breaks are planned within 34 kilometres of Yellingbo Forest, and no felling is occurring on seed bank sites in the Yarra Valley.   Prof Lindenmayer felt his warnings about the Leadbeater's possum habitat, which went back to his doctoral thesis in 1989, were falling on deaf ears.
   "We're knocking down 300 year old trees," he said.
   "It's going to be the year 2300 by the time we get them back again."

urn:contentItem:6F8J-M1S3-RX4M-70H7-00000-00'The fire was just plummeting': Family's close call with Mt Buninyong blaze2025-03-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:41ZLexisNexis'The fire was just plummeting': Family's close call with Mt Buninyong blazeMichelle Smith

The causes of Wednesday's two blazes remain under investigation.

The first that Coral Loader knew about a bushfire that burned within metres of her Mount Buninyong home was when a friend rang to say there was a fire on the mountain and check she was okay.

When she opened the door, flames were "plummeting" toward her home.

As she prepared to evacuate, there was just enough time to park son Corey 's car in a clearing over the road, run back to grab border collie Anzac and their emergency evacuation kit, and leave.

"(The fire) was just plummeting. It was on the border of our property, where there are some eagle nests, and I reckon we lost them," she said.

As she drove out her driveway, a Mount Buninyong CFA tanker pulled in and she told them to "cut fences, plough through, do what you need" to protect their home.

Driving along Yendon Number Two Rd she checked in on neighbours to make sure they were aware and headed into Buninyong.

A bulldozer created a fire break from the top of Mt Buninyong straight down through the Loader's property and CFA crews backburned up the mountain to meet the fire front and stop it reaching their home.

Fire got to within a metre of a row of cypress trees that run alongside their shed.

"If it had got into the cypress, the heat would have been too intense and we would have lost the shed," she said.

In all six fire trucks on her neighbour's side of the fence, and two on their property, kept the flames at bay.

Husband Rob raced home from work and stayed at the property overnight with CFA crews while Ms Loader, Corey and Anzac stayed with friends.

It's not the first time the family has evacuated or faced the loss of their home.

It was a close call during the Nash's Road, Buninyong, fire in December 2018, and Corey and his mum still had traumatic memories of the 2015 Scotsburn fire .

They moved to Ballarat so Corey, who has autism, could attend Ballarat Specialist School, after they lost their home in Baffle Creek, near Bundaberg in Queensland, to the Australia Day floods in 2013 which saw two metres of water flood their home, and the bridge to their property under 21m of water.

Ms Loader returned home about 6.30am Thursday and was able to come and go through a police roadblock which remained in place throughout the day.

While at home she could "hear trees crashing on our place" as burnt trees dropped limbs or crashed to the ground.

Forest Fire Management and other agencies conducted safety assessments of trees on the property.

Despite the blaze still burning, Ms Loader was keen to return home with Corey, once some repairs were made.

"They bulldozed through the water pipe because we've got a tank up the hill ... it is what it is so that's what is being repaired and then we'll discuss going home because there's nothing really left to burn on our place."

The cause of the Mount Buninyong blaze, which has burned at least 51 hectares, is still under investigation by fire authorities and police as crews continue to battle the fire, which is not yet under control.

A Watch and Act warning remains in place, with firefighters battling steep terrain and dry fuel loads, which is increasing fire activity on the mountain.

A community meeting is scheduled at the Buninyong Recreation Reserve from 4pm on Thursday, and will be live-streamed by the City of Ballarat and Moorabool Shire.

The cause of a second fire which broke out on Boak Rd, Mount Clear, just after midday on Wednesday is also still under investigation.

urn:contentItem:6DSM-2SN3-RS79-V20T-00000-00Bushfire threat remains high2024-12-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:41ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Bushfire threat remains highAmelia Swan

Efforts to prepare for hot new year weather were under way in bushfire-affected areas in the Grampians on Monday, as residents were allowed to -return home.

The milder conditions were a welcome change for fire crews entering a burnt-out area near Moyston where the fire broke free from the national park and claimed at least three homes last week.

Fire crews from as far as Noble Park, Rosebud and Lang Lang were mopping up and putting out smouldering logs on Monday.

A Forest Fire Management spokesman addressed communities at local meetings with an update about the fire situation.

Recently returned residents in Pomonal, Halls Gap and Moyston were told the edge of the fire that made a large run in Boxing Day's hazardous conditions had been extinguished, but there was a significant amount of work to be done to ensure the fire wouldn't get away from them again.

"As we go through summer we will get more hot dry weather. This is going to cause issues and put pressure on this fire," the spokesman said.

"We've seen it break out from areas that are behind control lines already. We need to remain vigilant." Crews have been backburning during the calmer weather to develop containment lines, with the spokesman saying the conditions were "ideal for them to implement this strategy." Residents were told an area on Mt Victory Rd and the sundial area near the southern part of Halls Gap were still concerning, but crews were working to contain it.

Towns in the Grampians remain closed for business, with the main streets of Moyston and Pomonal eerily quiet in what would be their peak season for visitors.

This follows reports the area has experienced a tourism -income loss of close to $1.9m as a result of the bushfires. Police have set up a roadblock outside Halls Gap allowing only residents through and have been out in force to deter looters. It could take weeks to reopen sections of the park.

urn:contentItem:6D75-D0T1-JC0X-K0RB-00000-00VIC:Banking on seeds to help save endangered possum2024-10-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:43:41ZLexisNexisVIC:Banking on seeds to help save endangered possumWODONGA Oct 20

  A battle to save a critically endangered possum is being fought on many fronts and multiple timelines.
   Victoria's Leadbeater's possum, known as "forest fairies" for their elusiveness, were thought to be extinct when they were rediscovered near Marysville in 1961.


   The state's faunal emblem, with its big eyes and bushy tail, relies on dense, damp areas in old growth forest and nests in hollows that take over 150 years to form.
   Less than 40 of the lowland subspecies exist today in a tract of the Yellingbo Forest, east of Melbourne, after most of its habitat was lost to logging and development.
   But a project spearheaded by state-owned statutory authority Melbourne Water aims to grow the creature's future habitat through a climate-modelled seed bank.
   The seeds have been collected from areas with climatic conditions similar to what is expected for the Yarra Valley in the next 25 to 65 years.
   The sources span from forests in Gippsland, in Victoria's southeast, to Wyong, north of Sydney.
   "We know that to save the lowland Leadbeater's possum from extinction, we need to protect and expand its habitat by growing forests that will be resilient to hotter, drier climates," Melbourne Water partnership coordinator Kacie Melfi said.
   Six species of native trees were shortlisted to help shore-up future habitat for the Leadbeater's possum.
   Melbourne Water is working with Zoos Victoria and Victoria's Department of Energy, Environment and Climate Action to identify land that could provide future habitat for the species.
   A collaboration between Zoos Victoria and Monash University focuses on the creature's gene pool to assure its survival.
   The organisations have successfully bred a hybrid of the highland Leadbeater's subspecies with its lowland counterpart in captivity, to help stem the inbreeding depression in the latter variety.
   "We've got 39 (lowland) individuals left in the wild; that's just nine breeding pairs," Zoos Victoria field officer Arabella Eyre told AAP.
   "We're really excited that we've recently produced our first hybrid joey."
   Previous attempts to move the highland Leadbeater's possums from their ash forest and sub-alpine woodlands habitat in Victoria's Central Highlands into lowlands populations haven't been successful.
   "That's why testing in captivity and having the ability to test that mixing in a controlled environment is really important for us," Ms Eyre said.
   Another key feature of the conservation program is to temporarily house juveniles, who can be lost to predators like cats or by wandering into unsuitable habitat.
   "The problem being a possum is when you hit your teenage years and it's time to go find a mate, there's not that many options left in the wild," Ms Eyre said.
   "We're able to collect those sub adults just before they disperse, take them back to Healesville sanctuary and kind of play possum matchmaker and then re-release them into the wild."
   Habitat loss remains a major challenge.
   "We've cleared over 90 per cent of lowland Leadbeater's habitat; they were originally distributed all the way down to Koo Wee Rup and the Bass River, and now only in this single reserve," Ms Eyre said.
   "The story of the possum's decline is really a story of the loss of habitat."
   While Victoria's environment department was a partner in conservation efforts like the seed bank project, its Forest Fire Management Victoria branch was levelling thousands of hectares for strategic fire breaks, forest ecology expert David Lindenmayer said.
   "This is in complete conflict with other really important, direct things that we could do right now, like not knock the animals' nest trees down that are 300 or 400 years old, that are going to take centuries to regrow," he told AAP.
   "One part of the department is not talking to the other part of the department."
   Victoria banned commercial native logging in January but a dead endangered greater glider possum found near fire break works in the Yarra Ranges National Park in May reignited debate over the state's forests.
   "The reality is there's 18,000 hectares of forest that hasn't regenerated (after commercial logging), and we're knocking down 300 year old trees for firebreaks that don't work," Professor Lindenmayer said.
   He said research had shown for more than a decade that logged forests became more fire-prone.
   But the department argues fuel breaks retained far more trees and couldn't be compared to disused logging coupes.
   According to Forest Fire Management Victoria, asset protection fire breaks protect towns and public assets, while landscape protection breaks give firefighters access to blazes in the bush and to back-burn.
   The organisation has established 1447km of fuel breaks, between 20m and 40m wide across Victoria, and has funding to extend to 6000km of breaks by 2030.
   Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman said regeneration and fire breaks were a proven and effective tool against bushfires.
   "In the Upper Yarra catchment, fuel breaks help us keep bushfires small and therefore protect communities, assets such as Melbourne's main water supply, and the environment - including protecting the habitat of the vulnerable population of Leadbeater's possum from bushfires," Mr Hardman said in a statement.
Forest Fire Management Victoria maps show no new strategic breaks are planned within 34 kilometres of Yellingbo Forest, and no felling is occurring on seed bank sites in the Yarra Valley.   Prof Lindenmayer felt his warnings about the Leadbeater's possum habitat, which went back to his doctoral thesis in 1989, were falling on deaf ears.
   "We're knocking down 300 year old trees," he said.
   "It's going to be the year 2300 by the time we get them back again."
